metadata.title: How to render your Tableau Viz as a GIF file | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to render your Tableau charts as a GIF file
metadata.description: A simple hack to GIF your Tableau data

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Our World In Data: Coronavirus (COVID-19) Cases
World Population Review: Gini coefficient by country

all_paragraphs: Our World In Data: Coronavirus (COVID-19) Cases
World Population Review: Gini coefficient by country
This article will show you two simple and quick steps you can take to make a GIF file out of an already dynamic Tableau visualization.

Nowadays, the proliferation of dynamic and effective data communication is also seeing charts being more and more prone to being communicated in an interactive way that is aligned with the type of digital media most people communicate with. GIFs are definitely a trend in this regard, and they can be potentially very effective when it comes to augmenting the degree of interactivity of your data charts and the way you present them to your relevant audience.

Therefore, I will walk you through a brief example on how to turn a Tableau chart into a GIF file, which can be then shared via reports/presentations to add a touch of interactivity to whatever content you will be sharing with your network.

The objective of this chart is to examine the correlation of income inequality, as estimated by the Gini coefficient, and a country’s total Covid-19 cases per one million inhabitants (data sources can be found at the top of the page), and see how the correlation appears to be developing over time. To do this, you are going to make use of two datasets and of Tableau’s Pages Shelf to add the first element of interactivity into our chart.

As a first thing, you can input the two data sources necessary for this example and join them using Tableau’s data source tab, as shown in the below image. You can use the “Country column” on the Gini coefficient table to perform a left join with the second data source, as to get you to a single table which features both the Gini coefficient and Covid-19 related columns (number of cases, tests, etc by date).

Just in case you will be following along this same example, notice that you might have to pre-process the country column’s format (i.e. capitalization of the country’s name on the Gini coefficient table) as to perform the left join correctly.
Once this is done, you can open a blank sheet an draw out your chart. I am sharing my chart below but feel free to develop it according to your own taste!

In the below view, you can draw a scatter-plot of the Gini Index vs the Total Covid-19 Cases per 1 Million inhabitants by Country. You can color each point on the plot to mark out the Country’s Continent and size the points according to each Country’s Population.
You can then filter the data for a relevant time period of interest using the Date column (for which you can also filter out any occasional null value) and for a particular Continent.

You now have drawn out the basis of the chart. To add interactivity to it, you can use the Pages shelf to break down the scatter-plot by each particular day (which represent a single “page” in the shelf) within the time period, and thus analyze how the correlation develops overtime. To keep track of the page name(which in this case is really the Date you are looking at on the chart for a particular frame of the Pages shelf), you can add an Annotation to visualize the date breakdown of each scatter-plot frame.
To do so, right-click anywhere on the chart, go to “Annotate” > “Area” > “Insert” > “Page Name”; once done, you can also format the annotation to your liking.
The Pages shelf is thus a great way to animate your chart. Doing so results in the below:
Now that you have your chart drawn up and animated via the Pages shelf, let’s see how to turn it into a GIF file format.

To record your Tableau animation enabled by the Pages shelf, you can use any screen recorder of your choice to video-capture the chart’s development over time. I personally use TinyTake by MangoApps but feel free to choose according to your personal preference here. With it, you can select a portion of your screen to record a brief video of the animation in action. And that’s all there is to this step! You can now save your video file locally and get to step 3, where you will turn it into a GIF!
In this last step you finally convert your video file (MP4, WebM, AVI, MPEG, FLV, MOV, 3GP and other video files) to GIF file format.
An online tool I find convenient is ezgif.com, which allows you to perform different and helpful edits to your video.

You can quickly upload your recording to their Video to GIF converter page. You can then tweak the video start time, the end time, the size, and the frame rate, which are going to determine the final length and number of loops your GIF is going to run for.
After this step, a useful last tweak is taking advantage of the site’s speed changer, as to have your GIF loop faster and/or slower.
You can now download and save your file as a GIF format and share it to wherever you like!

You might want to add a GIF touch to your data report or dashboard, Power Point presentation and any other relevant materials and or web page, such as this one where I have my GIF running as a neat alternative to a static featured image.
You are done! Hope these short steps will be useful in adding a bit of GIF fun & interactivity to your Tableau work. Thanks for reading!
